H0.text: An ice cube melting is the thing in Marta’s house that causes a decrease in entropy when heat is forced to flow from a cool spot to a warmer spot.

H1.text: The refrigerator is something in Marta’s house that causes a decrease in entropy by forcing heat to flow from a cool spot to a warmer spot.

H2.text: An egg frying is the process that causes a decrease in entropy because heat is forced to flow from a cooler spot to a warmer spot.

H3.text: The toaster is the household item that causes a decrease in entropy because it forces heat from a cooler spot to a warmer spot.

A4.text: Reversing the polarity of the voltage applied to the Peltier cells results in a heating rather than cooling effect.

A5.text: Heat cannot spontaneously flow from cold regions to hot regions without external work being performed on the system, which is evident from ordinary experience of refrigeration, for example.

A6.text: the reversal process and the original process, both cause entropy production, thereby increasing the entropy of the system's surroundings.

A7.text: The heat expelled from the room (the system), which the air conditioner transports and discharges to the outside air, always makes a bigger contribution to the entropy of the environment than the decrease of the entropy of the air of that system.

A8.text: In an isolated system such as the room and ice water taken together, the dispersal of energy from warmer to cooler always results in a net increase in entropy.

A9.text: Similarly, a refrigerator moves heat from inside the cold icebox (the heat source) to the warmer room-temperature air of the kitchen (the heat sink).

A10.text: The operating principles in both cases are the same; energy is used to move heat from a colder place to a warmer place.

A11.text: The heat pump works by the use of reverse valves inside a heat pump, enabling a switch from cooling to heating.

A12.text: The coefficient of performance of a heat pump is greater than one so the work required is less than the heat released, making a heat pump a more efficient form of heating than electrical resistance heating.

A13.text: Thus, when the system of the room and ice water system has reached thermal equilibrium, the entropy change from the initial state is at its maximum.

A14.text: Our above result indicates that the entropy of the system as a whole will increase during these processes.

A15.text: The law observes that, when the system is isolated from the outside world and from those forces, there is a definite thermodynamic quantity, its entropy, that increases as the constraints are removed, eventually reaching a maximum value at thermodynamic equilibrium, when the inhomogeneities practically vanish.

A16.text: As the temperature of a system approaches absolute zero, all processes cease and the entropy of the system approaches a minimum value.

A17.text: Such spontaneous heat transfer always occurs from a region of high temperature to another region of lower temperature, as described in the second law of thermodynamics.

A18.text: The main disadvantages are high cost for a given cooling capacity and poor power efficiency (a low coefficient of performance or COP).

A19.text: Thermoelectric cooling is far less commonly applied to refrigeration than vapor-compression refrigeration is.

A20.text: The toaster is a small electric appliance that uses radiant heat to cook sliced bread into toast.
